page.title: 05Building Materials
page.content: The heavy Wealden clay yields several building materials. Winklestone, or Sussex Marble, is found in the north. In places the layer of Winklestone is 40 ft down, but at Old House Farm, where there were quarries, it is near the surface. As recently as 1960 blocks were dug up from Stonepits Field, at the farm, and were fashioned into polished columns to support the old winklestone altar slab of West Chiltington Church. This was found below the 'new' altar, where it had been buried during the Reformation. Winklestone takes a fine polish and was used for floors, tombs, fonts and altars in many churches and houses in the County. An example can be seen in Saucelands, an old house near Coolham, which has a solid winklestone plinth. This 'marble' is not used now, as the fossilised shells tend to drop out.
